raw_text:
Giant waves damage S Asia economy
 
 Governments, aid agencies, insurers and travel firms are among those counting the cost of the massive earthquake and waves that hammered southern Asia.
 
 The worst-hit areas are Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia and Thailand, with at least 23,000 people killed. Early estimates from the World Bank put the amount of aid needed at about $5bn (£2.6bn), similar to the cash offered Central America after Hurricane Mitch. Mitch killed about 10,000 people and caused damage of about $10bn in 1998. World Bank spokesman Damien Milverton told the Wall Street Journal that he expected an aid package of financing and debt relief.
 
 Tourism is a vital part of the economies of the stricken countries, providing jobs for 19 million people in the south east Asian region, according to the World Travel and Tourism Council (WTTC). In the Maldives islands, in the Indian ocean, two-thirds of all jobs depend on tourism.
 
 But the damage covers fishing, farming and businesses too, with hundreds of thousands of buildings and small boats destroyed by the waves. International agencies have pledged their support; most say it is impossible to gauge the extent of the damage yet. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has promised rapid action to help the governments of the stricken countries cope.
 
 "The IMF stands ready to do its part to assist these nations with appropriate support in their time of need," said managing director Rodrigo Rato. Only Sri Lanka and Bangladesh currently receive IMF support, while Indonesia, the quake's epicentre, has recently graduated from IMF assistance. It is up to governments to decide if they want IMF help. Other agencies, such as the Asian Development Bank, have said that it is too early to comment on the amount of aid needed. There is no underestimating the size of the problem, however. The United Nations' emergency relief coordinator, Jan Egeland, said that "this may be the worst national disaster in recent history because it is affecting so many heavily populated coastal areas... so many vulnerable communities. "Many people will have [had] their livelihoods, their whole future destroyed in a few seconds." He warned that "the longer term effects many be as devastating as the tidal wave or the tsunami itself" because of the risks of epidemics from polluted drinking water.
 
 Insurers are also struggling to assess the cost of the damage, but several big players believe the final bill is likely to be less than the $27bn cost of the hurricanes that battered the US earlier this year.
 
 "The region that's affected is very big so we have to check country-by-country what the situation is", said Serge Troeber, deputy head of the natural disasters department at Swiss Re, the world's second biggest reinsurance firm. "I should assume, however, that the overall dimension of insured damages is below the storm damages of the US," he said. Munich Re, the world's biggest reinsurer, said: "This is primarily a human tragedy. It is too early for us to state what our financial burden will be." Allianz has said it sees no significant impact on its profitability. However, a low insurance bill may simply reflect the general poverty of much of the region, rather than the level of economic devastation for those who live there.
 
 The International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies told the Reuters news agency that it was seeking $6.5m for emergency aid.
 
 "The biggest health challenges we face is the spread of waterborne diseases, particularly malaria and diarrhoea," the aid agency was quoted as saying. The European Union has said it will deliver 3m euros (£2.1m; $4.1m) of aid, according to the Wall Street Journal. The EU's Humanitarian Aid Commissioner, Louis Michel, was quoted as saying that it was key to bring aid "in those vital hours and days immediately after the disaster". Other countries also are reported to have pledged cash, while the US State Department said it was examining what aid was needed in the region. Getting companies and business up and running also may play a vital role in helping communities recover from the weekend's events.
 
 Many of the worst-hit areas, such as Sri Lanka, Thailand's Phuket island and the Maldives, are popular tourist resorts that are key to local economies.
 
 December and January are two of the busiest months for the travel in southern Asia and the damage will be even more keenly felt as the industry was only just beginning to emerge from a post 9/11 slump. Growth has been rapid in southeast Asia, with the World Tourism Organisation figures showing a 45% increase in tourist revenues in the region during the first 10 months of 2004. In southern Asia that expansion is 23%. "India continues to post excellent results thanks to increased promotion and product development, but also to the upsurge in business travel driven by the rapid economic development of the country," the WTO said. "Arrivals to other destinations such as... Maldives and Sri Lanka also thrived." In Thailand, tourism accounts for about 6% of the country's annual gross domestic product, or about $8bn. In Singapore the figure is close to 5%. Tourism also brings in much needed foreign currency. In the short-term, however, travel companies are cancelling flights and trips. That has hit shares across Asia and Europe, with investors saying that earnings and economic growth are likely to slow.
llama3.2:1b:
Giant waves damage S Asia economy due to massive earthquake and tsunami. The worst-hit areas are Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, resulting in at least 23,000 deaths. Aid agencies and governments are struggling to estimate the cost of the damage.

The region's tourism industry is vital, providing jobs for millions, but many businesses and infrastructure have been destroyed by the waves. International agencies have pledged support, but details on aid needs are still unclear.

The World Bank estimates that $5 billion in aid may be needed, similar to the amount offered after Hurricane Mitch in Central America. The IMF has promised rapid action to help governments cope with the damage.

Many people's livelihoods and futures will be severely impacted by the disaster, according to the United Nations' emergency relief coordinator. Insurers are also struggling to assess the cost of the damage.

The region's economy is expected to suffer long-term effects from the disaster due to the risks of epidemics from polluted drinking water. The International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies has requested $6.5 million in emergency aid.
llama3.2:3b: At least 23,000 people killed in massive earthquake and waves affecting southern Asia, with Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand worst-hit. Estimated aid needed is around $5 billion, with International Monetary Fund (IMF) promising rapid action. Tourism is a vital part of the region's economies, providing jobs for 19 million people. Damage covers fishing, farming, and businesses, with hundreds of thousands of buildings destroyed by waves. Insurers are struggling to assess the cost of damage, but expect it to be less than $27 billion.
gemma2:2b: Southern Asia was devastated by a massive earthquake and tsunami.  At least 23,000 people were killed, causing extensive damage. The region's economies are heavily reliant on tourism, but many businesses and homes have been destroyed, and the extent of the damage is still being assessed.  International organizations like the IMF and Red Cross are providing aid, while insurance companies will likely face a smaller bill than Hurricane Mitch. Economic growth in the region has been rapid, but the disaster may significantly slow this progress.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key ideas:

1. Government aid from the World Bank is estimated to be $5bn after Hurricane Mitch.
2. Aid for Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand - at least 23,000 people killed - expected to be $5bn (£2.6bn).
3. Tourism in southern Asia provides jobs and livelihoods for millions of people, but is severely damaged by the disaster.

Summary:

A massive earthquake in southern Asia has caused extensive damage, with more than 19 million people affected. Aid agencies are planning to help with financing and debt relief for countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, Myanmar (Burma), and several other countries. Many tourists have lost their jobs and businesses have also been severely damaged in the area. Governments are coordinating aid plans and international cooperation.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Giant waves have damaged economies in southern Asia, including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, killing at least 23,000 people and costing billions of dollars in aid, tourism, and insurance claims. The World Bank expects a $5 billion cost similar to the 1998 Central America hurricane disaster. Airlines are canceling flights due to travel disruption, leading to potential financial losses for airlines and investors.
qwen2.5:3b: Giant waves have severely damaged southern Asian economies, particularly Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, where at least 23,000 people died. The World Bank estimates aid needs at about $5bn, similar to post-Hurricane Mitch levels in Central America. Tourism is crucial with over 19 million jobs dependent on it in the region. Damage spans fishing, farming, businesses, and housing. International agencies pledge support; IMF promises financial assistance for affected countries. The UNHCR seeks $6.5m for emergency aid due to health risks from waterborne diseases like malaria and diarrhoea. Many travel resorts are hit hard, affecting crucial economic sectors and leading to cancelled flights and trips, negatively impacting share markets in Asia and Europe.
opencoder:1.5b: Giant waves damage S Asia economy. The worst-hit areas are Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand with at least 23,000 people killed. The damage covers fishing, farming, and businesses too, with hundreds of thousands of buildings destroyed. The governments of the stricken countries need to invest in supporting them. Insurers are also struggling to assess the cost of the damage, but some big players believe the final bill is likely to be less than the $27bn cost of the hurricanes that battered the US earlier this year. Some countries are planning to help recover from the weekend's events. The region with the highest demand for aid includes Sri Lanka and Maldives islands.
smollm:1.7b:
The following text summary is concise and accurate:

Summarize the article "Giant waves damage S Asia economy" in 500 words or less.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text concisely by preserving key ideas and details. The user specified to output only the summary without any explanations or formatting. Let me start by reading through the entire passage carefully.

First, it mentions that massive waves in S Asia have caused significant economic damage. The countries affected are Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, with at least 23,000 deaths. Early estimates from the World Bank showed $5 billion aid needed, similar to what Central America offered during a hurricane.

Tourism is crucial for these economies, providing jobs for over 19 million people in southeast Asia. The Maldives islands have two-thirds of all tourism jobs there. But many areas still suffer from fishing, farming, and other economic losses due to the damage.

International agencies are supporting efforts, with most agreeing it's too early to gauge the extent. The IMF has already pledged support for some countries but is not ready for others yet. Some agencies like Asian Development Bank have warned of delays in their responses.

The US earlier suffered from $27 billion in natural disasters, so this region may be a new worst disaster. There are concerns about long-term effects due to potential epidemics from pollution. The UN's coordinator warned that livelihoods and entire communities could be destroyed quickly.

Reinsurance companies like Swiss Re and Allianz are seeking aid. They're concerned with waterborne diseases affecting health, but other countries are offering cash assistance. The EU is delivering aid in euros, and the US State Department is exploring regional support.

Tourism is vital for local economies, especially in places like Sri Lanka, Phuket, and Maldives. These areas have good growth rates in southeast Asia. Other countries are also supporting tourism efforts, which brings in foreign currency but has caused some cancellations in travel companies affecting shares.

Putting this all together, I need to create a summary that captures the main points without getting bogged down in details. Start with the main issue: massive waves causing economic damage in S Asia. Mention the key countries and deaths. Then talk about tourism's role in job creation. Highlight the difficulties in assessing damages and the support efforts. Also include the UN's warning on long-term impacts and growth concerns from other countries.

I need to ensure I capture all these elements succinctly, making sure it's clear and flows logically.
</think>

Massive waves caused devastating economic damage across S Asia, with Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand being the primary affected regions. At least 23,000 people died, estimated aid needed was $5 billion, similar to Central America's $10 billion response for Hurricane Mitch in 1998. Tourism is vital for local economies, creating jobs for over 19 million people globally. The Maldives islands saw two-thirds of its tourism jobs there, but many areas still suffer from economic losses. International agencies are supporting recovery efforts, most agreeing it's too early to measure damage. The IMF has pledged support in some regions but remains unprepared for others. The US faced $27 billion in disaster damage, prompting a new worst disaster. Concerns about long-term effects due to potential epidemics and the dilution of aid from poor countries highlight the urgency. Reinsurance companies seek $6.5 million, with financial burdens influenced by health challenges like malaria and dysporia. Tourist resorts like Sri Lanka, Phuket, and Maldives are key to local economies, contributing $8 billion or more in Asia. Growth rates in southeast Asia are up 45% for the region, while other countries saw 23% growth. Investors warn of slowdowns due to travel cancellations affecting shares across Asia and Europe.
tinyllama:1.1b: Giant waves cause devastating damage in southern Asia, impacting hundreds of thousands of lives and causing massive losses of property and businesses. The worst-hit areas include Sri Lanka, Thailand, and the Maldives islands, where at least 23,000 people have died and over $10bn (£5.2bn) in aid is needed to cope with the economic impact. Tourism is a vital part of the region's economies, with two-thirds of all jobs depending on it. International agencies such as the World Trade Organization (WTO) have pleaded for quick and effective aid, while insurer companies are struggling to assess the scale of damage due to their business operations being halted. The US State Department has pledged $6m (£2.1m) in aid, with other countries also urging assistance. Many communities will be devastated by the loss of property and businesses, and immediate steps need to be taken to provide emergency aid.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summarize the article as follows: In southern Asia, a massive earthquake and tsunami caused widespread destruction, including substantial damage to the tourism industry. Countries in the region are facing significant financial burdens, both from insurance claims and from loss of earnings due to the disruption of travel and business operations. The International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies have announced $6.5 million in emergency aid for affected regions, but there is no clear idea of the actual costs for governments and businesses. Major players in the tourism industry, such as Swiss Re and the European Union, are also facing significant losses due to the disaster. While some countries may be able to recover by rebuilding or expanding their tourist destinations, others face a more long-term challenge: addressing the spread of waterborne diseases, particularly malaria and diarrhoea.
phi:2.7b:
The massive earthquake and waves hitting southern Asia have caused significant damage to the region's economy, impacting countries like Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, among others. Governments and aid agencies are counting on a financial package of over $5bn (£2.6bn) for the recovery efforts. Tourism is a vital component in the economies of these affected countries, providing jobs to millions of people. However, damage extends beyond just tourism, affecting fishing, farming, and small businesses. International organizations like the IMF are ready to provide support, but governments must decide if they want it. 

Insurers are also struggling to assess the cost of the damage, with Swiss Re estimating that the final bill may be less than $27bn - significantly lower than the damage caused by US hurricanes earlier this year. The overall dimension of insured damages is expected to be below $10bn. While this is primarily a human tragedy and it's too early for companies like Munich Re to estimate financial burdens, Allianz claims there will be no significant impact on its profitability.

The International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies are seeking funds to provide emergency aid. The biggest health challenge is the spread of waterborne diseases. 

The European Union has pledged $6m for immediate aid while other countries have also promised assistance. It will take time for businesses and companies in the region to recover from this disaster. The tourism industry, which accounts for a significant portion of local economies, is particularly affected. Travel companies have cancelled flights and trips, causing shares across Asia and Europe to fall. Overall, the economic consequences are likely to slow down growth and earnings.
orca-mini:3b: Summarizing the given text, the statement highlights the devastating impact of the earthquake and waves that struck southern Asia, causing significant damage to several countries including Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand. The article also mentions that hundreds of thousands of buildings and small boats were destroyed by the waves, and tourism is a vital part of many economies in the region, providing jobs for millions of people. However, the article also emphasizes that it is too early to assess the extent of the damage, and several players believe that the overall dimension of insured damages may be less than the US hurricane damages this year. The article further reports that several countries have pledged cash aid, while others are preparing to send aid workers and rescue missions. The text also mentions that travel companies are cancelling flights and trips, affecting the tourism industry, and investors are predicting a slowdown in economic growth.
hermes3:3b:

Giant waves causing earthquake and damage in S Asia, affecting Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, Thailand, costing at least $5bn aid, tourism-dependent economies facing large job losses, international aid agencies pledging support, UN emergency relief coordinator warning of long-term effects potentially as devastating as the tsunami itself.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A massive earthquake and waves damaged southern Asia, particularly affecting Sri Lanka, India, Indonesia, and Thailand, where at least 23,000 people were killed. The World Bank estimated the required aid amount at around $5 billion, comparable to the funding provided after Hurricane Mitch in Central America. Tourism, a vital part of the economies of the affected countries, was severely impacted with 19 million jobs dependent on the industry in the Southeast Asian region. Other sectors like fishing, farming, and businesses were also damaged, resulting in hundreds of thousands of destroyed buildings, small boats, and irrigation systems. International agencies pledged their support, while insurers struggled to assess the full cost of damages. The European Union promised $3 million in aid, and several other countries also committed funds. Travel companies canceled flights and trips, impacting shares across Asia and Europe, leading to expectations that economic growth would slow down.

The economic impact is estimated to be around $5 billion, comparable to the aid provided for Hurricane Mitch in Central America.
